Topic.Title: Revenues grow 20% ish, fulfillment cost 40% ish...

Message.Msg: Even gross margin growth, which was touted as substitute for revenue, has slowed (35% down from 40%+). I don't know why some pundits keep quoting gross margin % which is clearly a meaningless measure given the changing mix of 3P and 1P sales. It seems reasonable to look at absolute gross margin $$ growth, but again that too is slowing. Gene Munster said that investors would be looking for the "hope" of margin improvement this Q - that's the word he actually used, not improved margins but the hope. I don't think we saw even that here.

Topic.Title: somebody tell me the bull case here again.

Message.Msg: i'll play along but no position. Investors strongly believe in Jeff Bezos, as opposed to, say, Tim Cook of apple. And Amazon is really a collection of a few big businesses under one roof and each business lines are leading segments in the industry they compete in. When you look at apple, it is just smart phones. When you look at Walmart, it is just distributor of goods. When you look at at say EQIX, a leading cloud storage computing company, and NFLX, a media content provider - Amazon is a collection of all these businesses under one umbrella, so investors believe Jeff Bezos will hit a few home runs in the long run. Crazy valuation, I agree and that is the only way I can see why people buy at 1000x PE.

Topic.Title: Earnings Drop - AMZN goes up - The Emperor Has NO Clothes

Message.Msg: Here's my take; Amzn did dump 1000's of kindles on the market to take USE away from say AAPL. They expand their online digital content, so they can compete with NFLX and AAPL and Barnes n Noble/Borbders...so far Borders is gone, Barnes is close, and with the improved watching content NFLX may take a hit, but more Kindles or a set-top box is needed. AMZN music is better in my opinion to AAPL's store, but like AAPL, getting people hooked is a long and hard road. Once AMZN gets people hooked...the profit margins on Dig.Content is HUGE, so the current multiple on this company is with that expectation drive revenue and earnings, will it happen one day? who knows? Sure AMZN doesn't make much margin on the physical #$%$ they sell,...but for the market place sellers, they make 15-25% on every transaction. 15-25% for doing nothing but letting people sell their own #$%$! Plus, those sellers can store their #$%$ at AMZN (for a fee)...AMZN has already created the warehousing for their own stuff so they're getting paid to store their own stuff. All-in-all, AMZN is making money with the HOPE that one day this magic switch is flicked and they then traunce their competitors because of all the future use anticipation, the big question is how long, and will that switch ever get flipped! I have no positions, and never will

Did I hear the CFO properly that days payable increased to about 68 from 62 last year? That's the kind of thing businesses day when they are under stress... Topic.Title: amazon revenue growth is NOT as impressive as they PUMP and vs stock valuation

Message.Msg: Anyone can grow gross margins by sinking excessive capital into fixed/capital assets. But, the thing is that those don't just grow fixed cost. They drive additional operating expense that does not scale down well. I encourage all of you who are independent investors to look at fulfillment and gross shipping cost as a percent of net sales compared to Q4. They grew. The expansion drives semi-fixed cost which will hurt in non peak season. Look at YOY (aside from extra Prime shipping transfers) and the story is the same.

Topic.Title: Follow the cash...

Message.Msg: Amazon has almost $2B in accrued liabilities. Extending days payable is against a backdrop of resistance from the FBA increase will not go over well. If we have a macro shock, the cash crunch could be huge (far higher gift card intensity, sales drop reverse cash from working capital). I hadn't really factored in the gift card risk. But, if things go south, they'll use those before putting up new cash. Amazon has already levered up (debt to book equity is pretty high given book equity is under $9B...). Not much more to do there...

Topic.Title: I think by tomorrow morning we will get the direction it's going...

Message.Msg: PJ: IMHO CapWorld isn't stupid money. It persuaded the reflexive traders that AMZN was really great when in reality there was no alternative but to buy given the size of its position. In conjunction with a few quants, CapWorld (IMHO) painted the tape to encourage technical traders to load up. In the process, retail investors buying index tracking ETFs got to load up on this #$%$ at sky high valuations thanks to tacit collusion and rebalancing (and to sell AAPL at a discount...).. Wall Street is always innovating a way to capture dramatically more value than it creates. Most people don't realize how much of their retirement is taken in fees. ETFs have been cutting into them. WS used to be about things that created value -- real investing and investment banking (IPOs, M&A, etc). These days, it is just a vehicle to churn paper assets (which creates no value in aggregate and is simply a tax). Once great investment banking firms are all run/dominated by trading... I am truly afraid that it is too late for the government to do anything about the mess the banksters have created. I was at a nano conference at a table of mostly Ph.D.s and MBAs (many from academia) and I was the only person that did not have a gun and had not been loading up on ammunition. No BS. It blew me away. The folks that are capturing all the value now (having essentially engaged in glorified theft via predatory trading with asymmetric information and infinite leverage unavailable to all but select financial institutions) will find that it only makes them targets and undermines their safety if/when things do break. The NYPD and the National Guard wouldn't be able to do a thing to protect the wealthy in NYC or CT if real unrest broke out... And the masters of the universe would learn Maslow's hierarchy of needs the hard way... It looks like the Fed is "all in" on a strategy doomed to fail badly and this time I doubt the public will be so docile. I hope I'm wrong. I really do.

Topic.Title: Why iz it that no one trusts the stok market?

Message.Msg: What is so hated is the incessant "pain trade" where weak longs/shorts are being taken out (which roughly corresponds to retail, or those without the benefit of asymmetric information and leverage) and where the "financial analysts" and financial media (CNBC) simply try to rationalize the predatory trading rather than actually calling the BS for what it is. What is hated is the structure and behavior of the markets. WS has continued to push the market up assuming that retail is stupid and will buy in if they keep pushing. Likewise, TBTF banks assumed they could crush gold. Retail isn't as dumb as people think. They can sit in cash and gold indefinitely... Add to gold when it drops. Covers deflation and inflation (by which we really mean currency risk) without counterparty risk. They'll come back when these scam markets implode upon themselves...

Message.Title: The magic of accounting..
Message.Msg: Operation cash flow. Put last year's operation cash flow to build up stuff. Next year. Operation cash flow.. Put up this year cash flow to build up stuff. The reason that it has operation cash flow? it does not have to count the expense of last year's cash flow. At the end of day, not making any shiat. Tons of warehouse and equipment eventually will have to be replaced.. So where is the money? Operation cash flow. Growth for what.
